description: Borrowed from Dutch polder, from Middle Dutch polre, from Old Dutch polra, of uncertain origin.

entries.meaning: (geography) An area of ground reclaimed from a sea or lake by means of dikes. [from 17th c.]
examples: The patron saint of the Oude Kerk, Saint Nicolaas, the ‘water saint’, was also very popular, as he protected the sailors and those living on the polders from the dangers of the sea.

verbs.description: polder (third-person singular simple present polders, present participle poldering, simple past and past participle poldered)

entries.meaning: To reclaim an area of ground from a sea or lake by means of dikes.
